problem: What is the ratio of (a) the intensities, and (b) the amplitudes, of an earthquake P wave passing through the Earth and detected at two points 15 km and 45 km from the source?

steps.explanation: We will use the inverse-square law for intensity: I ∝ 1/r². For two different distances, this gives us I₁/I₂ = (r₂/r₁)². We will also use the intensity-amplitude relation: I ∝ A².
Define the variables from the problem: r₁ = 15 km (closer point) and r₂ = 45 km (farther point).
Part (a): Substitute the distances into the intensity ratio formula to find I₂/I₁.
Part (b): For the amplitude ratio, use the relation I ∝ A², which means A ∝ √I, so A₁/A₂ = √(I₁/I₂).
Substitute the intensity ratio to find the amplitude ratio.

solution:
Part (a) - Intensity ratio:
I ∝ 1/r² ⇒ I₁/I₂ = (r₂/r₁)²
Given: r₁ = 15 km, r₂ = 45 km
I₂/I₁ = (r₁/r₂)² = (15 km/45 km)² = (1/3)² = 1/9 ≈ 0.11

Part (b) - Amplitude ratio:
I ∝ A² ⇒ A ∝ √I
A₂/A₁ = √(I₂/I₁) = √(1/9) = 1/3 ≈ 0.33
